div3.head:
[from the New Orleans Picayune]
Battle' the Spoiler.
div3.p:
The cry, which comes up most profoundly from the bottom of the hearts of the people of the North, at this crisis, is, that the South, which they fancy to be on the verge of being subjugated, must be made to pay the costs of the war. It is not so much a question of Government, or authority, or tenure, as indemnification, which they think is only left to be settled by acts of Congress, and enforced by armies of occupation.
They are, accordingly, seizing the lands and the cotton as fast as their troops advance divesting owners of their property, and carrying it off for the benefit of Government; and are entertaining such laws of confiscation as will subject everything within the territory of the Southern States, movable or immovable, to which they can make title by they robber plan of seizing it by force to the disposal of the Federal Government.

We have more than once described in various ways the burden of Federal indebtedness.
A very distinct idea of the weight of that burden, and the ruin which it is to bring upon somebody hereafter, may be gathered from a reference to the takable capacity which the United States have exhibited in their former history during their career as a Government and in times of national difficulty.
A few figures will expound more clearly than column of speculation how largely this Southern war transcends in its costliness all the undertakings of the Government since its foundation, even including all its expenditures for its own support from the first day of its existence, and how more desperate the necessity for further expedients for relief.
We take for a basis of exhibit the statement of Mr. Spalding, of New York, a member of the Committee of Ways and Means in the Federal House of Representatives, in a late speech on the finances, he computed the eventual debt entailed on the Federal Government by the war, in the most favorable event, and by the strictest conclusion, at $1, 800,000,000-- eighteen hundred millions of dollars.

Turning to the official tables made up at the U. S. Treasury, to the 30th June, 1860, the last year of the undivided Union, we find that the total expenditures of the Federal Government, from its beginning in March, 1789, to that day, amounting to $2,151 8,828 twenty-one hundred and fifty millions of dollars.

So, the attempt to enslave the Southern States will have cost, for the beginning of the war, as we esteem it from the most invariable estimate of its completion, as the invaders count it, six- sevenths of the whole amount which served to support the whole Federal Government, in all its branches, for seventy-one years, during which it carried on the war with Great Britain and the war with Mexico, and sundry small, but not inexpensive Indian wars in Florida, in the Northwest, in Utah and upon the Pacific coast.

The war is, however, but just begun in an interminable career of cost.
There are but the first expenses of the experiment and they have already, by contestant, reached an amount which must rapidly transcend the whole expenditure of the Government of the United States when the Union was entire, for three quarters of a century.

How these sums were raised is rather interesting item of the . Nearly four hundred millions were raised by loans and treasury notes.
The actual direct contributions from all other counties, from 1789 to 1860, were as follows.

All the receipts of the Federal Government, during its whole existence to the beginning of this war, and, therefore, just about equal to Mr. Spalding's estimate of what the war will have cost if it stops soon.

It must be noted that this eighteen hundred millions of dollars is only the debt which the Federal Government will have contracted beyond its available means.
The cost of the experience is therefore still greater.
This is what computed will remain to be paid by somebody, and the Federate are assuming to decide that it is to be paid by us.

But this sum of eighteen hundred millions is to be first borrowed somewhere.
The robbery of the South is to come afterward, in order to make a fund for redemption.
They will have to wait a good while before they realize much out of that sort of success, but such is their calculation.
The comparative magnitude of the borrowing to be done, may be estimated by reference to these tables.
The aggregate amount which the Government of the United States raised by loans and the issue of treasury notes during its entire term, from 1789 to 1860, was $380,621,170.72. This includes large amounts negotiated for the extension of bonds already due, and the re-issue of treasury notice.
The largest amount in any one year, $35,000,000, was raised in 1815, under the impulses of peace, but the distresses of the Government for money, and the extreme difficulty in borrowing during the war, are matters upon which historians have dilated, in order to expose the trouble with which money is raised without an adequate system of finance and taxation to secure punctual repayment.
All the money which the Government obtained during the four years of the war by loans, &c., were less than a hundred millions of dollars.
The wholesome of $380,000,000, for fluctuating debts renewing and repaying, was spread over the seventy one years. Now a new debt is run up by a portion of the disjointed Union in less than two years, which, by confession, cannot be less than five times the whole aggregate of all the sums borrowed and paid, and reborrowed and repaid again, for its entire existence of seventy-one years.

To get rid of this mountain of debt is now the general object of the war of the North.
They are adding to it with a spendthrift recklessness, because they know that they can never carry it by their own resources, that it must bankrupt them inevitably and speedily, and that their only chance for relief join the whole sale plunder of the Southern people, the assure not only of the products of their farms, their annual crops, and all the profits of their future industry, but their whole capital of lands and labor to be the spoils of conquest, to help their enemies pay for the expenses or destroying their liberties.

This plan of warfare is the resource of a condition of finances confessedly desperate.
There is no object for the war but that of plunder.
The spoliation of the South is the only refuge of the North from utter ruin.--The fury which prompts it gives rise to desperate exertions, but it produces, on the other hand a corresponding energy of resolve, and a fixed purpose to make the desperation of the assault with unflinching — and if the extremity should require it, of desperate resistance.
Every man who has anything, or expects to have anything, in the South, feels an additional incentive to make his a life-time struggle, against the enemy who comes to rob his family of their homes, or his country of its liberties.
A whole people will keep their lands for themselves with their swords, or they will make those into which the robber forces his way a burden, which his sword must be always drawn to keep — and in which the bullet of the rightful heir, or his avenger, may find him, in the midst of his entrenchments.

div3.head:
From Island.
No. Ten.
div3.p: --The New Orleans Delta speaks of the arrival in that city of Lieut. Julius Elbe from Island No.10, and says:

q.p:
Lieut. Elbe confirms all that correspondents have related respecting the operations at the island, and its situation and that of its vicinity.
He came by land across the peninsula to a point below Tiptonville, whence he came in a Confederate steamer to Memphis.--The steamer ran the blockade of the enemy's batteries on the Missouri shore under cover of night.
Although Confederate batteries of heavy guns have been planted on the opposite Tennessee shore, it is still hazardous to pass the enemy's batteries in the day-time — The following special or fere from Gen. Trudeau will be read with interest:

div3.p: Headquarters Heavy Artillery, Madrid Bend, March, 16, 1862.

The Brigadier General commanding the Heavy Artillery returns his thanks to Col. Steadman, 1st Alabama regiment; Captain Rucker, his officers and men, at Battery No. 1; to Captain Barney Hughes, A. A. Gen'l--, Lieut. Lane, of the Artillery Staff; Lieut. Noland, Company R. Heavy Artillery; Lieut. Howell, Lieut. Caruthers, Sergeant McGaun, of Capt. Jones's company, and their men, for gallant and meritorious conduct before the enemy on the 17th and 18th inst., Brig Gen.
Jas,
Comr'g Artillery 1st District,
Western Department.

div3.head: The Chops.
div3.p:
--The growing wheat crop says the Greenville (Tenn,) at present is more promising than we recollect of overseeing before at this season of the year.
It is well set and the piece showing quite green.
The Milledgeville Recorder gives an encouraging account of the crops of wheat and other small grain in Georgia.

div3.head: Worthy of Imitation
div3.p:
Col. Blanton Duncan, of Kentucky, now in Virginia, offers to subscribe two thousand dollars towards building an iron clad gunboat at Richmond for the defence of that city.
He truthfully says;

q.p: "There are hundreds of rich men in our community who can give from five hundred to five thousand dollars each and not miss it."

div3.p:
It is proposed that the boat shall cost seven hundred thousand dollars. The sum of two hundred thousand has been already conditionally pledged.
There are many rich men in all our cities, parishes, and counties throughout the Confederacy, who could give thousands of dollars, "and not miss it," towards constructing iron- clad vessels like the Manassas and Virginia.
Will they do it, or will they wait for the enemy to capture the towns on our water courses by means of Ms gunboats, and thereby subject themselves to oil the evils which must follow?
The property of rebels shall be conflicted, say Lincoln, Seward & Co, to pay the cost of the war, in what condition, then, will be the property of our rich men?
They will be in a disagreeable dilemma; either they will have to take the oath of allegiance to the Lincoln Government or lose their property.
Their movable property they will never be able to recover, at least there will be very small chance for it, and their land not until the enemy shall have been expelled.
Will it not cost less to prevent the enemy from obtaining possession of these lands than to drive him off when they are once in his grasp?--Better down with the dust how while it may act as a preventive than wait to apply it as at remedy There are, we doubt not, hundreds of men in this State who could contribute their five, ten, twenty, or fifty thousand dollars for the construction of battering rams, "and never miss it" scarcely feel themselves inconvenienced thereby.
All such should recollect that the Lincoln Congress has passed a bill to take possession of the land and negroes of Southern planters wherever the invaders can obtain a foothold, and proceed to the cultivation of cotton for the Government.--The perjured conspirators have at last thrown off all disguise, and openly proclaim their intention to rob the Southern people of their property, both land and negroes, and lease them out at so much per annum to the conquerors.
for the benefit of the despoiling Government.
It is the highwayman coming with torch and sword, and proclaiming aloud his intention to rob everybody he meets who restate him — to desolate the land, and finally to appropriate it to his own use. We cannot hereafter reproach him with hypocrisy, be plumply advertises us that he is a wholesale robber and intends to plunder us!
He does not scruple to avow it in advance.
If this do not rouse our rich men, nothing can. If this do not loose their purse strings, nothing will.
If their eyes cannot see the standard of which the enemy defiantly flaunts in their faces, then those eyes are covered by an impenetrable him.

But we think the enemy has cast aside all disguises, all pretences of good will, and of respecting the rights of the Southern people, too soon for the success of his purposes.
His legal advertisement to the South of his intention to perpetrate wholesale robbery will run through her like an electric shock, and nerve the whole Southern people to dispute his progress inch by inch, with all the weapons God and nature have given them.--N. O. Bull

div3.head: The Prince of Wales.
div3.p:
--The following letter, though unimportant in itself, is interesting as being almost the first public effort of the heir to the British Crown to fill the place of his late father as nearest adviser to the Queen.
It is addressed to the Royal Horticultural Society:

div4.p:
Prostrated with overwhelming grief, and able at present to turn her thoughts but to one object, the Queen, my mother, has constantly on her mind the anxious desire of doing honor to the memory of him whose good and glorious character the whole nation in its sorrow so justly appreciates.
Actuated by this constantly-recurring wish, the Queen has commanded me to recall to your-recollection that her Majesty had been pleased to assent to a proposal to place a statue of herself upon the memorial of the Great Exhibition of 1861, which it was intended to erect in the New Horticultural Guarders.

The characteristic modesty and self-denial of my deeply-lamented father had induced him to interpose to prevent his own statue from filling that position, which properly belonged to it, upon a memorial to that great undertaking which sprung from the thought of his enlightened mind, and was carried through to a termination of unexampled success by his unceasing superintendence.

It would, however, now, her Majesty directs me to say, be most hurtful to her feelings were any other statue to surmount this memorial but that of the great, good Prince, my beloved father, to whose honor it is in reality raised.
The Queen, therefore, would anxiously desire that, instead of her statue, that of her beloved husband should stand upon this memorial.

Anxiously; however humbly, to testify my respectful and heartfelt affection for the best of fathers, and the gratitude and devotion of my sorrowing heart, I have sought, and have with thankfulness obtained, the permission of the Queen, my mother, to offer the feeble tribute of the admiration and love of a bereaved son, by presenting the statue thus proposed to be placed in the gardens under your management.

div3.head: Great Destitution among the English operatives.
div3.p:
--Since the 1st of January, the applications for public relief among the Manchester operatives have exceeded 200 daily.
The Guardian, of a recent date, says:

q.p:
Of the 84 cotton miles, 53 are working full time, and employing 15,131 hands; 23 short time, employing 7,162 hands; 8 are stopped entirely, and 1,738 hands are thrown out of employment.
Of the 13 miles, three are working full time, and giving employment to 944 hands; 7 short time, employing 1,864 hands; and 8 are entirely stopped, and 1,930 hands thrown out of employment.
Of 19 small ware mills, 14 are working full time, and employing 2,340 hands; 5 short time, and employing 1,463 persons, while 90 are entirely cut of employment.

Of the 2 prize works, it is working full time, and employing 4 hands, and the other shortime, employing 50 hands; while 220 are entirely out of work.
Of 35 dye works, are working full time, and employing 1,063 hands, 16 short time, employing 4,054 hands while one is entirely stopped, and 416 hands thrown out employment.
Of 47 machinists, 40 workers are on full time, employing 6,114 hands; 7 are on short time, employing 986 hands, and 1,098 are out of work.
Of 25 foundries, 22 are working full time, employing 8,318 hards; 1 short time, 2 hands, while 725 are out of employment.
Last week 28, 653 persons were working full time, and this week 28,375; last week, 11,860 short time, and this week, last week, 6,156 were out of employment, while this week, there are 6,221.

div3.p:
--We will sell upon the premises, on Thursday, the 10th day of april, commencing at 4 ½ o'clock P. M. the valuable three story Brick House, in the cast side of Brook Avenue, near to Broad street, and now in the occupancy of Dr. Dillard.
It is accepted for any is business, and has ample accommodation above for a large family; is supplied with gas and water, and is in perfect order, having been recently erected.
The lot has the usual front and depth, and tuns back to a wide alley.

James M. Taylor & Son.

div3.head: Valuable land in the county of Chesterfield
div3.p: nearly adjoining Manchester, at Auction — The recent purchasers of the estate formerly owned by Charles H. Rhodes. Esq. finding that it contains more land than they wish to cultivate, we will sell, by request, on Tuesday, the 8th day of April, commencing at 1 o'clock, upon the premises, that portion thereof (with the exception of one lot) which lies between, and fronts upon, the River Road and the Manchester Turnpike, fronting the residence of Mr. A. C. Pulliam and others.

The land to be sold comprises 263 acres embracing the Frog, level tract, with the dwelling thereon, and runs down to the Toll-gate at the upper and of Manchester.
The whole of this land lies beautifully for cultivation.
Some of it has been highly improved.
Some of it is fresh land, and the remainder is heavily set in woods.
Its elevated situation and nearness to Manchester, as well as to the very heart of Richmond, render this property highly valuable for cottage seats, market gardens, or for general agriculture.
It has been subdivided, according to a map which may be seen at our office, into lots ranging from 2 to 70 acres; thus affording to all an opportunity of gratifying their inclination as to quality.

Terms One-third cash, the remainder at 8 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by trust deed.
The purchasers to pay the taxes for 1862.
Jas. M. Taylor & Son,
mh 28 Auctioneers

div3.head: Most valuable Brick Residence
div3.p:
On the North Side of Main, Between 1st and Adams Streets for sale, and the Valuable Private Residence at the North East Corner of Main and 17 Streets, at Auction.--We will sell upon the premises on Monday, the 21st day of April, commencing at 4½ o'clock P. M. the very valuable private Residence located on the North side of Main between 1st and on sts. sts, now in the occupancy of R. H. Dibrell. Esq. It contains 11 large rooms, with closets, bath house, hot and cold water, gas and water through the entire building together with large Brick Kitchen, containing 4 rooms: also, a Brick Stage, Carriage House, Smoke House, and other buildings.
This house is admirably arranged for the accommodation of a large sized family, and is in excellent order.
It is located in a very desirable neighborhood and convenient to business.
The lot locate feet and extends back 165 feet to a wide.
paved alley.
--Also--

A valuable Building Lot adjoining on the East, having the same front and depth.
It is well set with the choicest Fruit Trees, Grapes, &c.

Immediately after the above, will be sold the large Brick Residence located at the Northeast inter action of Main and 1st streets, adjoining the residence of Theodrick Robertson.
Esq. and now in the occupancy of Mr. Edwin Dibrell.
It contains about 10 rooms, and has attached a large Brick Kitchen.
The lot fronts about feet and runs back 160 feet on 1st street.

Terms.--One-third cash, balance a and 12 months, for negotiated notes, interest ad and secured by trust deeds.
Taxes and insurance for 1862 to be said by purchaser or purchasers.
Jas. M. Taylor & Son.
mh 2 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Very desirable Farm for sale
div3.p:
on the new Central road, in Henrico county, lying East of Richmond, at Auction.--At the request of John Curry, Sr, Esq., we will sell, on the premises, on Monday, the 7th day of April, 1862, commending at 12 o'clock M., this desirable Farm, seven miles from Richmond.
The farm contains 163 acres of land, and the improvements consist of a Dwelling-House, Kitchen, and the usual out-buildings.
There are about 80 acres cleared and is a high state of cultivation, on which about 50 bushels of oats have been seeded.
The balance of the land is in woods and good timber.
Adjoining the farm is a saw mill.
Persons wishing to engage in cutting timber will have a good opportunity to do so, as there is a good quantity of oak and pine timber on the farm.
The soil is most admirably adapted to the growth of early vegetables and fruit.
Persons wishing to purchase a moderate-sized farm, that has been highly improved by lime, &c., would do well to attend the sale, as the owner is very anxious to sell, his health not permitting him to attend to the cultivation of two farms.

The terms will be made very accommodating, and made known on the day of sale.
It may be bought privately before the day of sale, if desired.
James M. Taylor & Son,
mh 24 Auctioneers.

div3.head:
By Richard Cauthorn, Auctioneer.
sale of Miscellaneous articles.
div3.p: --On Monday, the 7th inst., at 10 o'clock, at my store, I will sell at auction a lot of articles, consisting in parts.
20 bbls. North Carolina Mullets,
10 boxes Manufactured Tobacco, part very fine,
40 boxes salted Backbone and Spare-Bibs.
6 bbls. Pickled Beef
75 pieces Bacon — Hame, Shoulders, and Sides.
Ground Coffee, Cigars, and sundry other articles.
Furniture.

Also, a lot of Furniture, consisting of — Bed and Bedstead, Hair and Shuck Mattress, one large, upright Show Case, or Glass House, two fine, large Mirrors, one Tailor's Board, with drawers, one handsome Card Table; one large, new, fine Wardrobe, one Crib, one Cooking Stove and Pictures.
Also, a Counter, Decanters, &c, &c.
ap 4 R. Cauthorn, Auct.

div3.head:
Stock of fine Ready made
Clothing, Merchant Tailoring Goods, &c. At Auction.
div3.p: --On Tuesday, 8th inst. at 10 o'clock, at the Store of Mark Nelson, on Broad, between and 5th streets, I will sell at auction, for cash, his entire stock of--
Ready-Made Clothing,
Merchant Tailoring Goods,
Piece Goods,
Cravats, Summer Clothing, &c.
All of the very best quality.
ap 4 R. Cauthorn, Auct.

div3.head:
By E. B. Cook, Auctioneer.
first class Bar-Room and Eating Saloon at Auction.
div3.p: --On Monday, 7th inst, at 4 o'clock P. M., I will sell on the premises, corner Main and 11th streets the first class Bar-Room and Eating Saloon, known as the "Morning Star Saloon," on 11th street, opposite the American Hotel.
The above Saloon has been fitted up in first-rate style, and is considered one of the best stands for an Eating Saloon in the city, being in the heart of the city.
The above Saloon can be purchased privately prior to the day of sale by application to E. B. Cook.
ap 2 Auctioneer.

div3.head: Administratrix's sale of real estate, &c., in Chesterfield county.
div3.p:
--Will be sold on the premises, on Thursday, the 17th day of April next, (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) a tract of land called "Chesnut Grove," near Clover Hill ts, on the Summit, containing 110 acres, one-half cleared, well enclosed, and in a high state of cultivation, balance in wood of orinal growth.
On this form is a comfortable dwelling-house with four rooms, and all necessary out-buildings, such as barn, dairy, stables, smoke-house, bath-house, &c. All the buildings are new.
On the same day will be sold all the perishable property on said estate, consisting of Horses, Cows, Sheep, Hogs, one Carriage, one Buggy, Household and Kitchen Furniture.
At the same time will be hired out for the balance of the year, three Negroes--two women, and one man.

Terms of Sale--For the land, one-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months purchaser giving negotiable notes, interest added, title retained until last note is paid.
For all other property, cash on delivery.
Maby Jewett.
Administratri of Wm, Jewett, dec'd.
mh 27--tds.

div3.head:
By James M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
four Houses and Lots, and four vacant Lots, on 17th and Marshall streets, at Auction.
div3.p: --We will sell, upon the premises, on Friday, the 11th day of April, commencing at 4½ o'clock P. M. four Houses and Lots, and four Vacant Lots adjoining, located as above.
1st Two Brick Tenements on the west side of 17th, between Clay and Marshall streets containing 5 comfortable rooms each, and now occupied by good tenants at fair rents.
Also, a vacant Lot at the corner of 17th and Marshall streets, fronting about 80 feet and running back 197 feet.
2nd. Two Framed Tenements on the South side of Clay, between 17th and 18th streets. The lots front 25 feet each and run back 166 feet.
Also, three vacant Lots immediately adjoining, fronting 25 feet and running back 166 feet each.
This property is desirable for residences or business stands, being contiguous to the Virginia Central Railroad Depot and the First Market, and adjoins the residence of Mr. Jno. Howard.

Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by trust deeds.
The purchases to pay the taxes and insurance for 1862. Jas M. Taylor & Son,
mh 27 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Elegant Household and Kitchen Furniture at Auction.
div3.p:
--By request of the Trustees is in a deed of record in the Clerk's Office of Richmond Hustings Court, we will sell on Monday, the 7th day of April, commencing at 10 o'clock A. M., the entire Furniture contained in the residence located on the north side of Marshall, between Adams and Foushee sts. The quality of the Furniture is excellent, was manufactured in the city, and is in first rate order.
In addition to the usual articles of Household Furniture are several fine Carpets, &c.

Terms.--Cash, in bankable funds, on delivery.
Jas. M. Taylor & Son.
ap 2 Auctioneers.

div3.head: One of the most desirable business stands, on the North side of Cary, between 13th and 14th streets, for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell on Monday, the 7th day of April, 1862, commencing at 11 o'clock M, that most desirable business stand, at the corner of Cary and Virginia streets, on the North side of Cary street, fronting 80 feet on Cary street and running back to an alley.
The house has been recently built, with granite front, four stories, besides cellar.
This property is justly regarded the most valuable in market, from its contiguity to the various depots and business portion of the city.

Terms.--One third cash; the remainder at 6 and 12 months, or negotiable notes, interest added secured by trust deed.
Taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.
Jas M. Taylor & Son.
ap 2 Auctioneers.

div3.head:
Very desirable Framed Residence of the South side of Main St. Between culvert and Cherri streets.
In Sidney, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell, upon the premises, on Monday, the 7th day of April, at 4½ o'clock P. M. a very comfortable and well arranged Framed.
Residence located as above, and now in the occupancy of Mr. Wm.
B Davidson.
It contains 7 rooms, with closets, kitchen and all necessary out buildings, and is particularly adapted for the accommodation of a medium sized family.
The location of this house is as desirable as any in Sidney; is located in a very pleasant neighborhood, and within a few minutes walk of the business portion of the city.
The lot fronts 80 feet and runs back 189 feet to an alley 20 feet wide.

Terms.--One-third cash, the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes and insurance for 1862 Jas. M. Taylor & Son.
mh 27 Auctioneers.

div3.head: The valuable Farm known as "Oakland,"
div3.p:
in the county of Henrico, lying on the Chickahominy river, 10 miles North of Richmond on the Richmond, Fredericksburg and Potomac Railroad, for sale at Auction.--The subscriber will sell, at public auction, on Wednesday, the 9th day of April, 1862, upon the premises, commencing at 12 o'clock M, that most valuable, fertile, and beautiful M. known as "Oakland," containing about lying on the Chickahominy river, 10 miles North of the city of Richmond.
This farm prevents many facilities that make it very desirable.
It is bounded on the west by the R. F. and P. Railroad, on the north and east by the Chickahominy river, on the South by the land of John B. Ryall and others.
The Richmond and Charlottesville plank road runs through the tract, dividing the open from the wood land.
There are about 00 acres cleared, the balance heavily wooded. --This estate is under a high state of improvement and cultivation, and has been recently well manured and limed, well enclosed in five fields, with plank fence.
The buildings are large and spacious.
The dwelling is ample for the accommodation of a large family.--The barns, stables and out-houses are mostly new, and in good order, a well of excellent water in the yard.
8 or 10 never-failing springs on the place besides being watered by the Chickahominy for a long distance.--Adjoining this estate there is a good grist and saw mill.
There are about 700 fruit trees of various Kurds on the place.
It is proverbial for being healthy, and the neighborhood is excellent.
It has a turn-out, and adjoining is a smith a shop.
To appreciate this estate it is only necessary to view it, and those who may desire to do so are invited to examine the premises.
My son, residing on the farm, will take pleasure in showing it. I offer this valuable estate for no other reason than that my business engagements in the city require my whole time and attention.

Terms.--One-fourth cash, the remainder at 1, 2 and 8 years, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.
William Taylor.
F. S.--The property can be treated for privately.
Jas M. Taylor & Son, Aucts mh 26

div3.head: Very desirable Brick Dwelling, on Elmwood or Main street continued, in Sidney, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell, upon the premises, on Monday, the 7th day of April.
commending at 4½ o'clock P. M., the very desirable Brick Dwelling, located on the south side of Elmwood (or Main street continued,) at its interaction with Laurel street at

It contains several pleasant rooms, together with a kitchen, stable, and every necessary out- building, is located in a very pleasant neighborhood and nearly opposite to the Sidney Methodist Church.
The lot fronts 58 feet, and runs back 109 feet to an alley 20 feet wide.

Terms.--One-third cash, the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added and secured by trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes and insurance for 1862. James M. Taylor & Son.
ap 1 Auctioneers.

div3.head: One hundred and twenty beautiful Building Lots contiguous to the city of Richmond, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell, upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 8th day of April, commencing at 1 o'clock P. M., 120 beautiful building Lots lying east of, and contiguous to, the city of Richmond, on the road from 17th street to the Mechanicville Turnpike, and from any portion of which there is a fine view for the city.
This sale presents a rare opportunity for a profitable investment, as well as to persons desiring ots for building purposes.,

Pesons desiring to purchase, are respectfully asked to view the property before the day of sale, a at of which may be seen at the office of the auctioneers.
If desired, the property will be sold in squares or lots.
Terms.--One half cash the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, secured by trust deeds.
James M. Taylor & Son,
mh 26 Auctioneers.

Also A beautiful suburban Lot, of the 120 lots on Buston Hill advertised by us for sale on Tuesday, 8th April is one of five acres, soil a beautiful elevation and view of Richmond, at the end of 17th street, having a grove of order trees on the road leading to Mechanicsville Turnpike, running back to a spring branch of pure water, making a very desirable grazing lot or market garden. J. M. T & Son.
ap 1.

div3.head: Desirable Framed House and Lot on Federal street, in Stoney, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 8th day of April, commencing at 4½ o'clock P. M., the desirable framed House, on the north side of Elmwood, near to Grove street, now in the occupancy of A. B. Hall.
It contains several good rooms, Kitchen, &c., and adapted for a small-sized family, a well of water in the yard.
The Lot fronts 30 feet, and runs back 160 feet to an alley 20 feet wide.

Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
The purchaser to pay the taxes for 1862.
James M. Taylor & Son.
Auctioneers

Immediately after the shone sale, will be sold a large lot of Ground, on the north side of Westham Plank-road, fronting 170½ feet and running back on the east line of street feet to an alley wide.
It will be divided into lots of the usual front size. J. M. T. & Son.
ap Auctioneers.

div3.head:
By Goddin & Apperson, Auctioneers.
very valuable and attractive Private Dwelling on the South side of Marshall, between first and four sts for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 7th day of April, 1862, at half-past 3 o'clock P. M., the very excellent brick Tenement located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. Shields.
The lot has a front of about 30 feet, and a depth of 165 feet to a wide, paved alley.
The Dwelling contains eleven rooms; the rear building with kitchen connecting, contains five rooms, together with two water closets, bath room, (with hot and cold water,) store room, and coal vaults, and an excellent brick stable on the rear alley.
There is a private culvert, built of stone, (which belongs to the property,) which connects with the city culvert, and which carries off everything and keeps the lot perfectly dry.

Terms--One-third cash; balance at six and twelve months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed, or title retained.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.
Goddin & Apperson.
ap 3 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Trustees sale of valuable real estate on Brook Avenue and near Thereto.
div3.p: --By virtue of the provisions of a died of trust, from John P, S. aid and wife, dated 28th November 1860 duty recorded in Richmond Hustings Court, and also in Henrico County Court, and by the request of parties to said deed, I shall soil at public suction, on the premises, in the order advertised on M the Amt, 1862, commencing at 4½ o'clock P. M., the following valuable real estate, va.

1st.
A Lot on the west of Brook Avenue, fronting 130 feet, running back on its south line 181 feet, on its north line 1 0 feet, in rear 57 feet, and bounded on the north by the real estate for accept want by James A

2d.
A Lutcon ai two roads bring the south easterly division of l No. in Grahun's plan.

3d.
Lot No a fronting 31 feet on the southwest side of Brook Avenue running back to lot No. 6.
4th ots Nos 7 and 8 in Mr. John H. Mertert's plan fronting together 53 feet on the west Hac of Brook Avenue, running back 200 feet to Graham's addition.
5th. 150 feet of land, (with several houses thereon,) fronting 150 feet on the west line of Brook Avenue, running back 100 feet to Graham addition, conveyed to by N. C. Carpenter and wife.

6th.
A valuable Lot in a plan fronting about 35 feet on the cast line of Brook Avenue, running back 150 feet more or less, and opposite to the Grocery Store of Mr. John Clash.

Terms.--One-third cash, balance and 12 month, for negotiable note, interest added secured by a trust deed, or title retained.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.
Ed Y. Cannon, Trustee.
Sale by Goddin & Auct rs
ap 4

Neat and very Desirably Located Residence, on the West Line of fifth, between Main and Cary Streets, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 10th April, 1862, at 4 o'clock P. M., the near and very desirably situated Residence, located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. Francis T., Glasgow, and opposite the residence of the late James Scott, Esq. The Lot has a front of feet, and a depth of 120 feet, to a wide alley.
The dwelling has six rooms, besides brick Kitchen, and large new brick Stable and Carriage House.
The location is among the best in Richmond.

Terms.--One-third cash, balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.
Goddin & Apperson,
ap 4 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Valuable Farm of 308 acres, in Henrico county, on the Quicolson Road, 7 miles West of Richmond, for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sole at auction, premises, on Thursday, the 10th April 1862. at 11 o'clock A. M., that valuable and highly improved Farm located as above, (secondly owned by Mr. B. W. Green.) called.
Goy's, containing 308 acres, according to a survey to be exhibited at the hour of sale it best opposites to the residence of Mr. R. D. Carter and scanning the place on which Mr. Green now residence T for the part is highly improved.
The buildings on the place and suited to such an es The land lay a beautifully, and the crops now on it will indicate the thty of the s ll.

Terms.--One-third cash, balance at one and two years, for negotiable notes, interest added, payable half nearly, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.
Goddin & Apperson.
ap 4 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Most valuable and well-located Private Residence on the East line of Governor street, for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Wednesday, the 9th April, 1862, at 4½ o'clock P. M., either of those two remarkably well-built and admirably-located Tenements, on the cast line of Governor street, occupied the one by Dr. W. D. T. asants, the other by George W. Johnson, Esq. the purchaser to have choice of A single bid will be reserved by the owner, in order to prevent a sacrifice; and the enment selected by the purchaser is to be old subject to the rights of the tenant.
These tenements were built about ten years ago under the superintendence of Mr. Henry Exall, and no expense was spared to make them as perfect and durable in every respect as was practicable.
They are so well and favorably known, (and being on Governor street, opposite the Governor's Mansion,) that a more general description is deemed unnecessary.
They have all the usual accommodations for a first-class dwelling, and are believed to be in excellent order.

Terms.--One-fourth cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.
Goddin & Apperson.
ap 2 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Beautiful and highly attractive real estate,
div3.p:
on Church Hill, on Marshall, Broad, and Grace streets, for sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, in the order advertised, on Friday, the 11th April, 1862, at 12 o'clock M., that beautiful square of land on which Mr. Thomas Nowland now resides, bounded by Broad, Marshall, 27th, and 28th streets, having a front of 284 feet on each of the two former streets.
It will be subdivided into smaller lots of suitable size, according to a plat and survey, to be seen at the hour of sale, each lot running back 1 feet to a 20 foot alley.
On this square there stands a very large and well-built Brick Dwelling, which, by being repaired, could be made a most desirable residence.

After the sale of this square, will be sold a most beautiful Lot on the north side of Grace, between 28th and 29th streets, adjoining the two new brick tenements recently erected by Mr. George Turner, fronting 77 feet, running back 1 0 feet to an alley 15 feet wide.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 1 and 2 years, for negotiable notes, interest payable annually, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.
Goddin & Apperson.
ap 2 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Very excellent and well, located Private Dwelling.
div3.p:
on the North side of Leigh, between 8th and 9th Streets, for sale at Auction — We will sell at auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 10th April, 1862, at 6½ o'clk P. M, that large and well built Brick Tenement located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr Fred. W. Pleasants, and adjoining the residence of Mr. Geo. W. Gretter.
The house is in excellent order; has ten come and the usual servants' accommodations; is supplied with gas and water, and is, altogether, a first class dwelling.
The neighborhood and location is a very desirable one, and quite convenient to all the usual places of business.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance as and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser,
Goddin & Apperson,
ap 2 Auctioneers.

div3.head:
50 Lots at Rockette, in the plan of "Griffin's Spring," and a large Numbers of other Lots.
Some on Lester street, some is Fulton and some in Port Mayo, for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Wednesday, the 9th April, 1862, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M., about 50 Lots, in the plan of "Griffle's Spring" property, having fronts on each side of a continuation of Main st. and within three hundred yards of the Eastern corporation line.
A plan of the Lots can be seen at our office.
After which will be sold a valuable Lot on the east line of Laster street near to Nicholson at, fronting 40 feet, running back 94½ feet.

Also, five beautiful Lots in Fulton, in Square No. 7 each fronting feet on the south side of Nicholson street; and three Lots in Square No. 5, each fronting 30 feet or the south side of Graham street.
Also several beautiful Lots in Fort Maya, adjoining the grocery store of Mr. Thacthy Kerac, including, also Mr. Kerac's excellent store and dwelling.
The foregoing real estate presents an excellent opportunity for persons to invest their surplus
Terms.--One-third
mh 27 Goddin & Apperson, Aucts.

div3.head:
By Goddin & Apperson, Auctioneers.
valuable real estate on the West line of 10th, between Main and Cary streets, for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction on the premises, on Monday, the 14th April, 1862, at 1 o'clock P. M., the excellent Brick Tenement located as above, how in the occupancy of Dr. Patrick Cullen.
The lot has a front of 26½ feet; and a depth of 85½ feet, and bounded on the south by a 2 feet alley.
The location, is a most valuable one for business purposes.
Possession given 1st May next.

Terms.--One-third cash, balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.
Goddin & Apperson.
ap 2 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Two most valuable stores and Dwellings on the South side of Broad, between third and Fourth streets, for sale at Auction.
div3.p: --Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 8th April, 1862, at 4½ o'clock P. M. those two remarkably well built and admirably well arranged granite and iron-front tenements located as above, one of which is now in the occupancy of Mr. Thomas D. Quaries, and the other recently in the occupancy of Messrs. Crenshaw, Quaries & Co.

The tenement occupied by Mr. Quaries is a very large one, and is not only admirably well adapted to a Dry Goods Store, but the upper part is among the most convenient and well arranged for the accommodation of a large family to be found on Broad street.
The tenement recently occupied by Messrs. Crenshaw, Quaries & Co. is generally conceded to be the finest Dry Goods Store in this city.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at one and two years, for negotiable notes, (interest payable half yearly) secured by a trust deed, with privilege to the purchaser to anticipate the credit payments.
The taxes and insurance for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.
Goddin & Apperson.
mh 31 Auctioneers.

div3.head: The valuable-farm called "Cedar Hill." three and a Hals miles East of Richmond, containing 326 acres, together with personal effects thereon, for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--At the request of Charles Y. Morris, Esq. we shall sell at auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 8th April, 1862, at 11 o'clock A. M., the valuable Farm located as above, containing 326 acres, adjoining the lands of Dr. Wm.
A Christian, Dr. John N. Friend, and Col. She win McRae.
The improvements consist of a dwelling, containing five rooms, a stable, corn house, tobacco-houses, and other out buildings.
About 100 acres in high land, well set in clover, about 100 acres in and oak wood of original growth, which will field, it is said about 80 cords per sore.
The remaining 125 acres is in Chickahominy low grounds , on which about 100 bushers winter oats have been seeded.
The location is a very healthy one, and the neighborhood unexceptionable.
Immediately after the sale of the land, all the personal effects on the same will be sold, consisting of corn, fodder, shucks, straw, wagons, carts, mules, horses, and farming implements.
Possession given at once, if required.

Terms.--For the real estate, one-third cash, balance at 1 and 2 years, for bonds; bearing interest, secured by a trust deed.
For the personal effects all sums under $100 cash, over that amount, 4 months credit, for approved endorsed negotiable paper.
Goddin & Apperson,
mh 27 Auctioneers

div3.head: Beautiful Farm of 297 acres, in Henrico county, four miles North of Richmond, near the Brook Turnpike, and personal thereon, for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--At the request of Daniel E. Gardner, Esq. who is about change his business, we shall sell at public auction on the premises, on Monday, the 7th April, 1862, at 11 o'clock A. M. the beautiful Farm on which he resides, called "Spring Farm," containing 287 acres, adjoining the lands of Capt. John B Young, Mosses.
William Saunders, Abner Hillilard, and others.
The place is so well known that a particular description is deemed unnecessary.
There is about two hundred acres of open land in good heart, and one hundred acres in wood and timber.
There is on the place buildings suitable for the accommodation of two separate families, and two houses.
If desired, the place will be subdivided to suit the views of bidders.
The neighborhood is amongst the best in the county, and the place remarkably healthy.
It is only necessary, to examine the premises to be pleased with them.
After the sale of the land, all the personnel effects on the place will be sold, consisting of horses, mules, cattle, hogs, corn, oats, farming implements, &c.

Terms--For the land, one-third cash; balance at 6, 12, and 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchaser.
For the personal effects, all sums under $100, cash; over that amount, 4 months credit, for approved endorsed negotiable paper.
Goddin & Apperson,
mh 27 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Trustees sale of very valuable real estate in Sidney, on Grove street.
div3.p:
--By virtue of a deed of trust from the late William J. Hubbard, and Maria M., his wife bearing date the 19th June, 1856, duty recorded in Henrico County Court, we shall in execution of the said deed, and with the consent of the creditor and of Mrs Hubbard, proceed to sell, at public auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 7th April, 1862, at 4½ o'clock P. M., Of fair; if not, the first fair day,) the following real estate, conveyed by the said deed, viz: lot 48, in Sidney, [with the brick tenement thereon, now occupied by Mrs. Hubbard,] fronting 155 feet on the North side of Grove street, running back 250 feet on the East line of Clarke street; also, lot No. 61, adjoining the above, fronting 156 feet on Grove street, running back 267 feet on Clarke, and 271 feet on Harvie street; also two lots, Nos. 7 and 8, in Richard Anderson's plan, each fronting 31 feet on the South side of Grove street, running back feet to a 20 foot alley.
On one of these lots there is a most beautiful cottage residence; also, two other icty in Peticolas's plan, Nos. 21 and 22, each fronting about 30 feet, running back 179 feet to an alley; on one of these loss there is a neat framed dwelling, and on, the other a large brick foundry, of great value.

Terms--One-fourth cash; balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
The title to the foregoing real estate is believed to be good, but we will convey with the usual special warranty.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.
The foregoing real estate is the most beautiful in Sidney.
W. Goddin, Trustees.
mh 17 P. Roberts, Trustees.

div3.head: Ten beautiful, Lots on the North side of Grack street, between Belvidere and Henry streets, for sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Friday, the 11th April, 1862, at 4½ o'clock P. M. ten beautiful lots, in Morton's Garden, located as above, each having a front of thirty feet, and a depth of one hundred and fifty feet to a twenty-feet alley.
These lots are well enclosed, and have fine shads trees in front, and are most beautiful for genteel residences to be built on.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at one and two years, for negotiable notes, interest payable half yearly, secured by a trust deed.
The taxes for 1862 to be paid by the purchasers.
Goddin & Apperson.
mh 31 Auctioneers.

div3.head: By Dunlop, Moncure & Co., Aucts.
div3.p: Sugar, Coffee Molasses, &c. At Auction — On Tuesday, the 8th inst., commencing at o'clock, we, will sell at our auction store--
50 bbds. Sugar, ranging from fair to choice quality.
75 bags Rio and Cuba Coffee.
20 sacks Salt.
Pepper, Ginger, Pimento, &c.
Terms--Cash without re to weather.
Duni of, Monoure & Co.,
ap J Auctioneers.

div3.head: Receiver's sale.
div3.p:
--in pursuance of a ecres of the Confederate Stairs District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia.
Friday, the 18th inst, (if air; it not the next fair day.) proceed to left on the premises; public auction to the highest bidder, the trust of land lying in the county of Loc a, 1½ miles from Toquerville, known as the "State Hill Gold Mixing Tract," and containing 81 acres and 4 poles.

I shall at the same time sell all the personal, property upon said land, of one 120 horse power Steam Engine, one small 7 power Steam Engine, one I whim Chain 200 feet one Sheet-Iron Delly lub, one 4 inch weighing about one ton, and many other articles.

terms of --For the Land one third of the purchase money to be paid in cash, the balance in two equal at 6 out it mo who interest from the day of sale, the until the last payment is mads.
For the personal property, cash will be required.

div3.head: Receiver's sale of Procals.
