lg.l: But we worth the hireling knave
Who meets him, man to man!
But we worth the Hessian thief
Who meets him, man to man!
That the foe shall feel him
Blood shall stain his broad word
But we worth your staunchest slaye
Who meets him, man to man!
God! who would not gladly die
But we worth the hireling knave
Who meets him man to man!

div3.head: Richmond markets,April 4, 1862.
div3.p:
There is so little doing that the prices are hardly more than retail quotations.
All necessaries are inordinately high.
The Military Executive proposes to restrict the maximums of a good mary articles sold at the markets.
The order to this effect leaves them quite high enough.
Beef is certainly higher than it ought to be; yet it is not included in the list of regulated articles.

Money is superabundant and seeking investment, in the absence of means for its absorption in commercial enterprises.
Real estate has, therefore, advanced to a most extravagant appreciation.
Much is therefore thrown on the market.
What effect this will have remains to be seen.
Stocks continue firm.
Bread — Navy, 4 cents; Pilot, 5 cents; Butter and Soda, 8 cents per lb.
Bacon — Stock light and firm at 24 to 26 for hog round, Hams, 26a28 cents per lb.
Butter — The Provost Marshal has fixed the maximum of retail prices at 50, to take effect Monday.
Corn — We quote 80 cents per bushel.
Corn Meal--$1a1.65 per bushel.
Coffee — Rio, 75 cents per lb.; supply nearly exhausted.
Candles — Adamantine, 75a80 cents, Tallow, 23a25 cents.
$7.00; Family $8a$8.5c; all by the dray load.
Cement — James River, $2 50a3.00 per bbl.
Cotton--9½a10 cents per lb.
Cotton Yarns--None. Candlewick, 50 cents per lb.
Cheese — The limited lots of Country Dairy 35 cents per lb.
Dried Fruit--Peaches, unpeeled, from $2.25 to 2.50; Pealed, $5,00a6.50; Apples, $1.50a $1.75 per bushel.
Forage — Timothy, $1.70a$1.80; Clover, $1.60a$1.70; Sheaf Oats, $1.50a$1.60; Shucks, $7 ½c. a$1 per cwt.

Fertilizers — James River Manipulation guano, $60 per ton; stock small and rapidly reducing.
Mexican guano, $25; Sombrero, $35; Bone Ash, $40, Stocks exceedingly light.
Feathers — Quiet, at 37½ a 40 cents per lb
Flaxseed — Nominal; $1.50.
Flour — We quote Superfine at $7a$7.25; Extra $7,50 $7.75; Family $8.50a$9.
Hides — Green, 6 cents; salted, 9½cents; dry, 12a15 cents.
Iron--English refined and American, but a small supply, which is sold in limited quantities at 8 cents per lb.; Swedes, none in market.
Leather — Sole, 30a35 cts. per lb.; Upper $1 per lb.; Harness 75a80 cents; Rough Skirting 55a85 cts; Calf Skins $48a55 per dozen.--Stock of all kinds very light.
Lard — 21a27 cents.
Lime — Mountain unslacked, $2.00, to $2.50 per bbl.; according to quantity.
Molasses — New Orleans, $1.30 to 1.40 cts.
Nails — Old Dominion, 10a11 cents.
Offal (mill)--Bran, 30 cents; shorts, 36 cents. Brownstuffs, 30 cents; shipstuffs, 70 cents.
Oil — Tanners, $1,12a1.50; machine, $1.50a$2 per gallon.
Oats — We quote 80 cents per bushel, and stock large.
Rye--$1.50a$2.00 per bushel.
Seed — Clover Seed, $17a$18--latter by retail; Timothy, $5½a$6½.
Soda — Beat English, 40 cents per lb.

Sugars — Brown, 24a26 cents per lb., coffee, 27a23 cents.
All qualities firm.
Salt — Some sales of North Carolina Salt at $11 per sack of 100 lbs.

Tobacco — The breaks of Tobacco are small, and most of the Tobacco offered at this time is re-opened.
There is not so much animation in the market, and prices are lower.
We quote interior lugs at $2½a$2½, good $3a$3½ inferior leaf $5a$5½; good $6 ½17½; fine $8a$9½a$10.
Tallow — 15a16 cents per lb.

Wheat — Red $1 10al 20; white $1.15a1.25, and dull.
Few buyers these prices.
Wool — Market firm, and arrivals light 90 a 95 cents per pound.

div4.head: Cattle Market.
div4.p: Beef — We quote at $6.00 gross, which is 12 to 16 net.

Sheep — Supply light.
Extra quality, $8 to $9 gross.
Hogs — In demand at $18.50 to $14 net.

div4.head: Money matters.
div4.p:
Specie — We quote gold and silver at 60 to 75 per cent premium.
Very little doing.
Bank notes — Nearly all Southern Bank notes are taken on deposits by our Banks.--We note the following as rejected for the want of arrangement to make them current at Bank:

Georgia--City Bank, Augusta; Mechanics Bank, do; Bank of Augusta; Augusta Insurance and Banking Company; all 1 per cent. discount; and Bank of the Empire State, Rome, Ga., and North western Bank, Ringgold, Ga., 2 per cent discount.
North Carolina--Bank, of Lexington; Bank of Clarendon; Bank of Commerce, Newbern; Bank of Fayetteville, and Bank of Washington, all 1 per cent discount.
Sales of Stocks in Richmond--Reported by John A Lancaster & Son, for the week ending April 4, 1862.
Confederate States Bonds — sales at $98½.
Confederate States bonds--$100,000,000 issue — sales $4.
Tennessee State bonds--(Interest suspended,) last sales, $5.
Virginia 6 per cent, Registered Bonds, sales at 9
North Carolina State bonds — last sales 97½
Richmond City bonds — sales 102.
Petersburg City Bonds — sales 92½.
Exchange Bank stock — sales 98.
Farmers' Bank stock — sales, 95.
Bank of Virginia stock — sales 67.
Bank of the Commonwealth stock--sales 87½.
Old Dominion Insurance Stock — last sales, 25.
Insurance Company of the State of Virginia--sales 24.
Virginia Life Insurance Company Stock — last sales, $1.15.
Virginia Fire and Marine Insurance--32½
Richmond Fire Association Stock — last sales at $25½
Merchants' Insurance stock — no recent sales.
Va. Central R. R., 1st mortgage bonds — no recent sales.

mortgage bonds--80.

C. and A. R. R. 8 per cent, bonds — last sales $5.

Va. Central Railroad stock — sales 49½.
Richmond and Petersburg Railroad stock — sales 77½.
Richmond and Denville Railroad stock--75,
James River and Kanawha stock — no recent sales.

Officers declining to raise companies, or having companies already enlisted but not in any regiment, can correspond with the undersigned at Richmond, Va. Nat. Tyler,

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my store, on Tuesday morning, 15th instant, my negro Boy, Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto, thick set, about 5 feet high, 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me.
S. S. Cottrell,
ap 2--ts No. 129 Main street.

div3.head: $15 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my residence, in Ashland, Hanover county, Va., on Thursday, 26th March, my servant woman, named Fanny; about 20 years old; low in stature; ginger-bread color; rather long hair, and when spoken to has a pleasant look.
I purchased her from O. Cranz, trustee, in this city, last fall.
She may be lurking about the city.
I will pay the above reward of $15 if apprehended and delivered to me in Ashland, or lodged in some jail, that I may procure her.
ap f — 6t* Hiram James, Ashland.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Ten dollars reward will be paid by me for the delivery of a mulatto girl, named Jane or Jennie, aged fifteen years belonging to Mr. Brown, of Lunenburg, and hired to me by Mr. E. A. J. Clopton.
She left my house a week ago yesterday, and has since been on Church Hill. --She has a very full bead of hair and a scar on one cheek.
Ella Johnson,
mh 31--6t* In rear of Exchange Hotel.

div3.head: Twenty dollars Rewards.
div3.p:
Runaway, ten days ago, a Negro Boy, about eleven years old. Said Boy is black, stout Built, and stutters a little, and has a scar on his left forehead.
He is in Richmond, and was seen in the Old Market a few days ago. His name is Henry, and was brought to this city by M. A. Myers on the 5th of February last from Norfolk.
I will give the above reward for the delivery of said Boy to me, or secured in any jail, so that I can get him. A. Wolff,
mh 29--6t* 64 Main street.

div3.p: --All the males between the ages of 45 and 55, below 14th street, and cast of Broad, and within one mile of the corporation line, will meet for drill at the Washington Artillery camp ground this side of Howard's Grove, on Monday, at 3 o'clock P. M., according to the Governor's proclamation.

div3.head:
Attention!
Recruits
for Hampden Artillery.
div3.p:
The recruits from Hanover county who have enlisted in this company, will report at the Recruiting Office in Richmond, on 6th street, opposite the New Market, on Tuesday, the 8th inst, at 12 o'clock M. Those from Spotsylvania will meet at the office of John L. Marye, in Fredericksburg, on the same day, by 9 o'clock A. M., and proceed, under charge of a Sergeant, to the rendezvous in Richmond.
Those from Louisa, and along the line of the Central railroad, will report at the stations on this road recited in their several leaves of absence, on Wednesday morning; the 9th instant, in time to take the cars for Staunton.
Every man must observe this order.
No kind of excuse will be taken for a violation of it. It would be well for each recruit to bring two blankets and a serviceable pair of shoes or boots.
A uniform cap, knapsack, haversack, canteen, thick blanket, two under shirts, and two pairs of woollen drawers will be furnished each recruit at Staunton.
div3.closer:
law. S. Marye, Captain
ap 3--d3t&clt* Hampden Artillery.

div3.head: Wise Zouaves.
div3.p:
The undersigned is enlisting a company of Infantry for the 20th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, to be called the Wise Zouaves, in compliment of the memory of the late Captain Wise.
This company will be instructed by Mr. C. F. Pardigon in the Zouave drill of the French Infantry, and taught by him the bayonet exercise.
Being familiar in all its detail, and having aided Captain Car in the translation of the French works on Bayonet Exercise, his ability to instruct in that drill cannot be questioned.

Militiamen desiring to enter this service will apply to the undersigned, on 12th street, one door above Main.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid the men when mustered into the Confederate service
div3.closer: ap 3--1m C. F. Pardygon.

div3.head:
War Department,
Adjutant and Inspector Gen.'s office,
Richmond, March 24, 1862.
div3.p:
General Orders, No. 16--All leaves of absence and furloughs, from whatever source obtained, are revoked; and officers and men absent from duty, except on surgeon's certificate of disability, will return at once to their respective commands.
It is with extreme reluctance that the Department adopts a measure which deprives our patriotic soldiers of the relaxation they have so well earned; but the enemy presses on every side, and the necessities of the service demand new illustrations of that noble self-denial which has been so many times evinced since the commencement of our struggle for independence.
The furloughs of all who have engaged for the war, which are thus curtailed, will be extended hereafter, when circumstances permit.
But, judging from the past, no fears are entertained of an unwilling response to this call.
Those who have so many times proved their devotion to their country cannot be indifferent or backward in this hour of her greatest need.
div3.closer:
By order of the President.
S. Cooper,
mh 2.--6t Adjutant and Inspector Gen.

div3.head:
War Department,
Dj't and inst.
General's office,
Richmond, March 29th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 18.
1. The following Proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:
Proclamation:
By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus

"I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America do proclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the counties of Greenbrier, Pocahontas, Bath, Alleghany, Monroe-Mercer, Raleigh, Fayette, Nicholas, and Randolph; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualification of guardians, to enter decrees and orders form the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to access county levies.
and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in the counties aforesaid.
"In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name and set my seal this 29th day of March, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.
[Signed] Jefferson Davis."

II. Brig. Gen. Henry Hath is charged with the due execution of the foregoing Proclamation. --He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders; All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited and the distilleries will forthwith be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

III.
All persons infringing the above prohibition, will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a court martial, provided that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a Regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th Article of War.
div3.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
[Signed] S. Cooper, mh 3--6t Adj't and Inspector General.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., March 31, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, no. 12.
I. Huckstering in the markets of this city is so great an evil, that it has become necessary to abate it. The whole system is therefore abolished.

The practice of purchasing produce on its way to market is prohibited; persons found buying or selling in such case, within ten miles of Richmond, are liable to punishment at the discretion of a court-martial, and the produce will be forfeited to the person informing against the offenders.
The Provost Marshal will give every assistance to the Clerks of the Markets in enforcing the City Ordinance regulating this subject, and police officers under his direction will attend the markets for such purpose.
All purchases at wholesale in the markets until after the regular market hours is forbidden.
Persons found sleeping in the markets will be arrested and punished by a court-martial.
This order will go into immediate operation.
No hindrance whatever will be offered to country persons bringing produce to this market, but every facility afforded for the accomplishment of such purpose.

II.
The following tariff of maximum prices is established for the sale of produce in the markets, and none other will be permitted this tariff to go into operation on and after Monday, 7th of April, 1862.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig Gen. John H. Winder.
L. R. Page, Assistant
ap 1--1w Adjutant General

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p:

The undersigned having purchased the interest of Thomas Ellett in the late concern of Ellett & Weisiger, will continue the business at the same old stand, No. 167 Main street and hopes, by personal attention, to merit the former patronage of the house and the public generally.
Powhatan Weisiger.

div3.head: Co-partnership Notices.
div3.p: --as A Snyder and Amandus N. Walker have his day associated themselves in business, for the purpose of conducting the manufacture of Stoves in all its branches, and doing a general Foundry business.

They most earnestly ask the support of their friends to aid in making their work so extensive as to challenge foreign competition on both as to quality and price.
The style of the fire will be
Snyder & Walker
Richmond, April 1st, 1862.

div4.p:
After an experience of over ten years in this market, I feel competent to judge of the class of manufactures best adapted to your wants, and shall strive, with the increased facilities now at command, to make the business commensurate with your wants.
The business, under the new management of Snyder & Walker, will be increased in capacity nearly, four fold.
The works will soon be located at one of the most ral and convenient points in this city, so that for the future it is hoped the vexatious delays in filling orders, which heretofore caused so much inconvenience, will be avoided.
Accept my thanks for your liberal support and kind indulgence, and I most cordially invite your continuance to the new firm.

We are authorized to sell the valuable Farm, (in rear of the farm recently owned by Robert A. Lancaster, Esq.,) containing 40 acres, within three hundred yards of the new Fair Grounds.

This is really a beautiful location for a suburban residence.

div3.head: For sale.
div3.p:

The buildings consist of a large framed Dwelling, four rooms, two brick chimneys; Barn; Stable, and a well of good water in the yard.
Those wishing to purchase will call on.
ap 3--1w* Thos. W. P. Goodman.

div3.head: The beautiful Farm of 189 acres, called "West view," on the Westham Plank-Road, 4½ miles West of Richmond, for sale.
div3.p:
--We are authorized to sell the very valuable Farm located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. Edward McConnell.
This is probably the most desirable farm of its size now in market as the land is not only naturally of fine foundation, but has been greatly improved by fertilizers.
The buildings on the place are all in good order, having been built within the last ten years, and are ample for the accommodation of a large family.--The place so well known that a minute description is deemed unnecessary.
Persons disposed to invest their funds in land in the most improving neighborhood, are particularly invited to examine this estate.
Terms reasonable.
Apply to
Goodin & Apperson,
ap 2--6t Auctioneers.

Note, at interest to suit purchaser, or young negroes at value, or Confederate bonds at par, taken in payment.

ap 2--7t* Rome, Ga.

div3.head: A home for a Ref Joke.
div3.p:
--The subscriber offers for sale a part of the tract of land on which he resides, lying in Mecklenburg county, within three miles of Boydton, and seven of Clarksville.
This land is well adapted to the crops usually made here, but particularly adapted to the growth of wheat.
The improvements consist of a handsome and convenient dwelling, with six rooms, built within the last few years, and on the most improved plan; and all the necessary out-houses, yard, and garden, well enclosed.
The facilities to market are good, being connected by a good graded road with the railroad at Clarksville.
With these improvements I will sell 600 acres of land and upon it 100 bushels of wheat has been seeded the present season.
This property is located in a desirable neighborhood, being surrounded by good neighbors, good society and several churches.
Persons desiring to purchase can communicate with me by addressing me at Clarksville, Va. Possession will be given immediately.
Richard S. Baptist.

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--Privately, a number of Lots in Sidney, on Grace and Broad streets, just beyond the corporation line.
Also, in Manchester, Houses and Lots, on Hull street. One has attached to it a rich and productive garden.
The basement rooms may be used as stores.
And for rent or lease, Lots both in Richmond and Manchester.
Apply to. Dr. Brocks,
Corner Main and 12th streets.
Office hours, from 8 to 9 A. M., and from 3 to 4 o'clock P. M. ap 1--1m*

div3.head: Very beautiful and well located Private Dwelling, on the South side of Marshall, between 10th and 11th streets, for sale.
div3.p:
--At the request of Mr. W. A. Armistead, [who is about to remove to the country.] we are authorized to sell his valuable private Dwelling, located as above.
This dwelling was built about three years ago, and no expense spared to make it complete in every respect.
It has 10 rooms besides kitchen of 6 rooms, large stable and carriage house, with servants' room above.
There are marble mantels in six rooms, gas, hot and cold water, city culverts for drainage, cooking range, and every modern improvement usually found in a first-class dwelling.
It has on iron verandah and marble steps in front, and two-story portico in the rear, and the house is heated with furnaces.
The lot has a front of 36 feet and a depth of 150 feet to a wide, paved alley.
Altogether, this is among the most desirable residences in Richmond.
Apply to Goodin & Apperson.

div3.head: For sale
div3.p:
--An excellent location for a practicing physician.
A small Farm, with all necessary buildings.
in New Kent county, 25 miles from Richmond, containing 110 acres of land — about 60 acres opened, the residue heavily timbered.
Possession given immediately.
For particulars, apply to E. B. Seldes, of New Kent county, or at the northeast corner of 12th and Marshall sts., Richmond.
mh 29--6t*

div3.head: For sale.
div3.p: --Two excellent, well-built, and convenient Tenements, containing six rooms each, with the usual out-houses, and a well of water in the yard, which has been conveyed into each Tenement.

Also — A vacant Lot adjoining, 70 feet front and 132 feet deep.
This property is situated on Union Hill.
For particulars, apply to Isaac J. Mercer, or Smith & Harwood.

div3.head: 1434 acres of valuable land at the head of Valley street, and immediately in the rear of the city Alams House, for sale.
div3.p:
--We are authorized to sell the valuable property located as above, called "Catland," containing 14½ acres. It fronts for a long distance on Valley street, and can be divided into six lots of about two acres each.
This land has been occupied as a market garden, and is admirably adapted to early vegetables.
Apply to.
mh 29--6t Goddin & Apperson,

div3.head: Beautiful little Cottage Farm of ten acres, on the meadow Bridge Road, half mile Northeast of Richmond, for sale.
div3.p:
--We are authorized to sell the above valuable property, now owned and occupied by Col. W. M. McCarty.
The tract contains about 10 acres, and has on it an excellent dwelling and every building usually found on such a place.
The land has within the past two years been greatly improved, and is now in successful state of cultivation, and abounds in a vegetables, &c, of various kinds.
It is proverbial for its early vegetables, and as a residence, is a most desirable one.
Persons disposed to purchase, are particularly invited to examine the premises.
Terms reasonable.
Apply to
mh 29--6t Goddin & Apperson.

div3.head: Valuable Farm of 260 acres, in Hanover county, near to Goodall's Tavern, and five miles from Ashland, for sale.
div3.p:
--We are authorized to sell the above valuable Farm It is situated about five miles from Ashland contains 260 acres land, about 50 acres cleared, balance wood lane — oak, hickory, and pine, which will make excellent rail timber and fire-wood.
There is on the place a dwelling house, nearly new, containing eight rooms, and is a most excellent house, with a handsome two- story porch in front.
The house is in a beautiful grove of oaks, with good enclosure, and a well of excellent water in the yard.
It is one of the healthiest places in the State; has on it an excellent frame kitchen, with four rooms; also, a good smoke-house and dairy, and a large barn and stables.

This is really a most desirable place, and its nearness to Ashland makes it accessible to Richmond two or three times daily.
The neighborhood is one of the best in this section.
It is sixteen miles distant from Richmond, with the Brook turnpike leading to Richmond, thus having advantages of railroad and turnpike.
This place was improved, and is occupied by Captain P. Woolfolk, Jr., of the Ashland Artillery.
His family are now living there and will take pleasure in showing the place.
Possession given immediately.
Terms.--One-third cash, one third at twelve months, and one- third at 24 months. Interest to be added and title retained until the last payment is made.
Goddin & Apperson,
mh 24--10t Auctioneers.

div3.head:
Executive Department,
Richmond, Va., March 7, 1862
div3.p:
all Sheriffs and others collecting State Arms are desired to have the same boxed marked "Col. C. Dimmock, Richmond, Va.," and forwarded as soon as possible.
The compensation for collecting and the necessary expenses of transportation to this city, will be paid on the presentation of the receipts of Col. Dimmock
Approved,
City papers copy mh 7--1m
